content.body: Is the spec definition of “interactive content” https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/dom.html#interactive-content intended to include the SVG `a` element, or instead only intended to include the HTML `a` element?
I realize the definition _links_ only to the HTML element, but I wonder whether any implementations have assumed the SVG `a` element should be included.
Regardless, _should_ we explicitly include “the `a` element in the SVG namespace” in that definition of “interactive content”?
ljharb: you can't create a blank one
content.formatted_body: ljharb: you can't create a blank one

content.body: sideshowbarker: where does that definition have an impact on implementations? But yeah, generally I think <a> and <svg:a> should be treated the same.
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: where does that definition have an impact on implementations? But yeah, generally I think <a> and svg:a should be treated the same.

content.body:
> <@annevk:matrix.org> sideshowbarker: where does that definition have an impact on implementations? But yeah, generally I think <a> and <svg:a> should be treated the same.

For the `summary` element, when deciding whether an activation event somewhere inside the `summary` should toggle its `details`
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
sideshowbarker: where does that definition have an impact on implementations? But yeah, generally I think <a> and svg:a should be treated the same.
For the summary element, when deciding whether an activation event somewhere inside the summary should toggle its details

content.body: And  https://searchfox.org/wubkat/source/Source/WebCore/html/HTMLLabelElement.cpp#124 is one other existing place I could find in the WebKit sources at least
It seems like that rightly should be considering the SVG `a` element too — but that `if (is<HTMLElement>(it) && downcast<HTMLElement>(*it).isInteractiveContent())` won't catch it.
Yeah, hmm. Is svg:a the only interactive element outside of HTML?
